bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Robert P. Cooke, November 22, 1941

div1.p: Hench sends Cooke reprints of his yellow fever article and refers to a large copy of the Cornwell painting sent to Cooke by Kellogg. He discusses future research plans for his yellow fever investigation. Hench informs Cooke that Truby's autobiography will be published shortly.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Robert P. Cooke, November 22, 1941
div1.opener:
November 22, 1941
Dr. Robert P. Cooke
Lexington - Rockbridge Health Dept.
Lexington, Virginia
My dear Doctor Cooke:
div1.p:
I am enclosing a copy of my recent article in Hygeia and by
separate post I am sending twelve more. If you wish more be sure to let
me know. I believe Mr. Kellogg of Wyeth Bros. has sent you a large copy
of the painting--if not he will be glad to send you one or several free.

I have continued my investigations of the yellow fever story
and hope that I may have the privilege of visiting you sometime soon to
tell you what I have uncovered and to enlist your help in trying to clarify
certain confused details. I have so many questions to ask you I fear I
could only get satisfactory replies by visiting you sometime when I visit
my brother who is Professor of English Literature at the University of
Virginia.

In January I go to a medical meeting near Washington and hope to
study some long over-looked records of the Surgeon General's office. Mrs.
Hench and I hope to take our winter vacation in March and go to California.
Enroute I hope to see Dr. Pinto in Omaha and later visit briefly Mrs. Lazear
and General Truby. Did you know that the latter has written his autobio-
graphy--it is splendid and he expects to publish it shortly. There is
much about the work in Havana.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
